fields.Title of Presentation: Bridging the Gap: Using School Campuses for Scientific Exploration and Language Acquisition
fields.Description/Abstract: In recent years, education has emphasized the need for hands-on and active learning within the<br>classroom, but this learning environment should be expanded to include innovative teaching practices<br>that include the entire school campus. Learning outdoors has the potential to excite and reinvigorate<br>learners while capturing a broader spectrum of our student body including those that are language<br>learners or students who respond more to physical learning by doing.   Participating in fieldwork,<br>“provides a place to contextualize learning in real world settings, acquire and develop technical and<br>life skills and as a place to enjoy” (Fuller 2012).  As noted by Cooper and Wischemann (1987), these<br>outdoor spaces are valuable places for life learning and deserve much more attention for their<br>capacity to serve our campus communities’ need for study, relaxation, and aesthetic enjoyment. By<br>emphasizing existing outdoor spaces for learning, we can call attention to the value and need for<br>protection of outdoor spaces that are often overlooked and underappreciated. These experiences will<br>equip all students with the knowledge and skills required for a STEM-driven (Science, Technology,<br>Engineering and Math) future and enhance science lessons to support multilingual students’<br>engagement. We will provide examples from the campuses of Boise State University and Georgia<br>Gwinnett College of innovative ways to use campus grounds and resources for extending learning<br>opportunities beyond the traditional classroom environment.
